I see enum as a superior choice here because of the following reasons:

We don't allow users to make invalid choices (ex: subscriber=false, autoTruncate=true)

User Friendly - rather than asking users to set flags we let them choose a friendly enum name based on their functional requirements the internal implementation details of what flags we use to implement this are hidden from them.

timeline.author: tkaitchuck

replies.bodyText:
Is it invalid to set CONSUMPTION_BASED_USER_STREAMCUT and call this method? If so why?

There are 2 ways to use Consumption based retention on Streams.
One where the user provides the truncation stream-cut and the other where the stream-cut corresponding to the last checkpoint is used as truncation stream-cut. We want to publish the stream-cut corresponding to the last checkpoint only when the user has chosen the later option by specifying the value CONSUMPTION_BASED_AT_LAST_CHECKPOINT against the retentionConfig field.
replies.author: pbelgundi

replies.bodyText:
Additionally if the user is making a mistake if this is set to "no_impact" should it silently do nothing or throw?

If the user choses NO_IMPACT, when the stream is configured for Consumption Based Retention its Stream-Cuts won't be published to Controller and it would essentially become a non-subscriber RG where it can read from the Stream but its reads do not impact Stream truncation.

replies.bodyText:
I think of the three options as:
"No need to extend retention for this reader group beyond the configured minimum"
"Extend retention until the readers have read the data (and checkpointed) up to the configured maximum"
"Extend retention up to the maximum unless explicitly released"
The call used by the third option also makes sense in the case of the second. It's just not needed.
In terms of names, we could try to express this as either:
RETAIN_UNTIL_CHECKPOINT and RETAIN_UNTIL_RELEASE
or if not "release" whatever verb we want to associate with the method call, like maybe UPDATE
Or we could try to get the idea of "retain data until" out into the enum class name and just have single word alternatives. Like just DEFAULT or CHECKPOINT. (Not sure what to call the manual option).
Or we could frame it is the "retention streamcut policy" in which cases the values would be NONE, AT_CHECKPOINT, and MANUAL. This might require a bit more explanation.

replies.bodyText:
What if instead of adding a new type to the RetentionPolicy enum, we just overloaded the methods in the StreamConfig?
Instead of: TIME, SIZE, and CONSUMPTION and the methods bySizeBytes, byTimeMillis, which take a single value and byConsumption which takes two longs and a unit which is either TIME or SIZE we instead have:
just TIME, and SIZE and then have withTimeRangeMillis and withSizeRangeBytes which each take a min and max arg for time/size.
In this case calling bySizeBytes is equivalent to passing the same value as the min and the max for withSizeRangeBytes (except under the hood we can optimize to do fewer RPCs).
This means that all streams are always use CBR (it's just that some have the same max and min) and so we don't have to explain it as a distinct concept, instead we just say the reader group can request data be retained and when they do so it will be retained provided it is less than the stream's configured max.
